questions.text: A pharmaceutical company conducted a double-blind clinical trial comparing a new antidiabetic drug to a placebo. The study enrolled an equal number of participants in both arms. Based on the data below, what are the Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) and Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) for adverse effects? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) RRR 11%, ARR 1%

 

Calculation -

 

  • Relative risk reduction (RRR): Percentage reduction in one outcome (E.g. Death or Adverse outcome) comparing one group (New drug) with another group (Older drug or Placebo)
  • Absolute risk reduction (ARR): Reduction in outcome (E.g. Death or Adverse outcome) comparing one group (New drug) with another group (Older drug or Placebo)
  • Event is taken as Occurrence of adverse outcome in the given example

 

In the given question,

 

Event rate Drug = 1603/15225 × 100 = 10.5% (0.105)

 

Event rate Placebo = 1804/15225 × 100 = 11.8% (0.118)

 

Hence,

 

  • Relative risk of Event rate = Event rate drug/Event rate Placebo = 0.105/0.118 = 0.9
  • Relative risk reduction (RRR) = (Event rate Placebo – Event rate drug)/Event rate placebo = (0.118)–0.105)/0.118 = 0.11 = 11%
  • Absolute risk reduction = Event rate Drug – Event rate Placebo = 0.105 – 0.118 = – 0.013 = – 1.3%

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) reflects the proportionate reduction in risk between two groups, while the Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) provides the difference in risk between them

questions.text: A family consumes only polished rice. Which of the following combination of vitamin deficiency and enzymatic defect will be present in this family? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine – Transketolase

 

This is the correct combination. Consuming polished rice can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Transketolase is an enzyme involved in thiamine-dependent reactions, and its activity can be affected by thiamine deficiency, leading to various health issues, including beriberi, which is associated with thiamine deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin - Glutathione Reductase: This combination is not relevant to the consumption of polished rice. Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and glutathione reductase is not directly related to this deficiency.

 

Option C. Thiamine - Transaminase: While thiamine deficiency can affect various enzymes, transaminase is not specifically associated with thiamine deficiency related to polished rice consumption.

 

Option D. Riboflavin - Transketolase: This combination is not relevant to polished rice consumption. Riboflavin deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and transketolase is not directly related to riboflavin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The consumption of polished rice leads to thiamine deficiency which leads to defective transketolase activity.

 

Polished rice undergoes milling, which removes the outer bran layer rich in B vitamins and other nutrients

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common cause of bipedal edema? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Venous Insufficiency

 

Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) typically leads to asymmetric leg swelling, where one leg is more affected than the other. In cases of CVI, the swelling is often unilateral, and if bilateral, it is usually asymmetric. This makes it the least common cause of bipedal (symmetric) edema among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lupus Nephritis: This condition affects the kidneys, leading to fluid retention and typically causing bilateral leg swelling. It is a common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Option C. Heart Failure: This systemic condition causes the heart to pump blood inefficiently, leading to fluid buildup in the lower extremities and symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Option D. Chronic Liver Disease: This condition results in decreased protein synthesis and portal hypertension, causing fluid retention and symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic venous insufficiency typically causes unilateral or asymmetric leg swelling, making it the least common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

choices.text: Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis decreases
Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Transferrin receptor 1 iron responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Ferritin mRNA concentration iron responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis increases

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the internal iron homeostasis in iron-deficiency anemia? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis

 

In iron deficiency anemia, there is an increase in transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis.

 

 

Progressive depletion of iron reserves first lowers serum iron and transferrin saturation levels without producing anemia. In this early stage there is increased erythroid activity in the bone marrow.

 

Anemia appears only when iron stores are completely depleted and is accompanied by low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.

 

The serum iron and ferritin are low, and the total plasma iron-binding capacity (reflecting elevated transferrin levels) is high. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation to below 15%. Reduced iron stores inhibit hepcidin synthesis, and its serum levels fall and this in turn facilitates iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis decreases: This statement is incorrect. In iron deficiency, ferritin synthesis decreases as the body conserves iron, but the ferritin mRNA concentration does not increase.

 

Option C. Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis: This is incorrect because in iron deficiency, transferrin receptor 1 expression increases to maximize iron uptake.

 

Option D. Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis increases: This is also incorrect. In iron deficiency, both ferritin mRNA levels and ferritin synthesis decrease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In iron-deficiency anemia, transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increase mRNA concentration and synthesis to enhance iron uptake, while ferritin levels decrease as the body attempts to conserve iron.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, pg 1231-1234

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with medication presents to you with sudden onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray was done, which is shown below. How will you manage this patient? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intravenous nitroglycerin

 

The patient presents with symptoms and signs indicative of pulmonary edema, which is evident from the chest X-ray showing interstitial edema and classic bat-wing appearance, suggestive of cardiogenic pulmonary edema. The history of hypertension and non-compliance with medication supports the diagnosis, as poorly controlled hypertension can lead to increased afterload, left ventricular failure, and subsequent pulmonary edema.

 

Intravenous nitroglycerin: Nitroglycerin is the treatment of choice in this scenario as it helps to reduce both preload and afterload by dilating veins and arteries. This leads to a reduction in pulmonary congestion and improvement in symptoms of breathlessness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous salbutamol: Salbutamol is a bronchodilator used primarily in the treatment of asthma or COPD exacerbations, and primarily not used intravenously. It is not indicated for managing pulmonary edema and does not address the underlying cause of fluid accumulation in the lungs.

 

Option C. Nebulization with salbutamol: Similar to intravenous salbutamol, nebulized salbutamol is used for bronchodilation in conditions like asthma or COPD. It is not effective in treating pulmonary edema and does not relieve the symptoms caused by fluid overload in the lungs.

 

Option D. Oxygen and antibiotics: While oxygen might be necessary to support the patient’s respiratory status, antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a concurrent infection, which is not suggested by the patient’s presentation. The primary issue here is fluid overload due to heart failure, not an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, intravenous nitroglycerin is essential to reduce preload and afterload, thereby alleviating pulmonary congestion and improving the patient's symptoms.

choices.text: There is no association present between the factor and the disease
There is a positive association between the factor and the disease
There is a negative association between the factor and the disease

questions.text: A cohort study was conducted to investigate the association between a specific factor and a disease. The calculated risk ratio was found to be 1. What does this signify? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. There is no association present between the factor and the disease

 

In a cohort study, the risk ratio (RR) compares the risk of disease in the exposed group to the risk of disease in the unexposed group.

 

  • An RR of 1 signifies that the risk of disease is the same in both groups. This implies that the factor being studied does not influence the occurrence of the disease, indicating no association.
  • RR< 1: Exposure/incidence is protective. It lowers the risk for expressing the outcome
  • RR = 1: No association between an exposure that delineates the cohorts and the outcome
  •  RR > 1: Association between an exposure that delineates the cohorts and the outcome

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. There is a positive association between the factor and the disease: This would be indicated by an RR greater than 1, suggesting that the exposed group has a higher risk of disease.

 

Option C. There is a negative association between the factor and the disease: This would be indicated by an RR less than 1, meaning the exposed group has a lower risk of disease (the factor might be protective).

 

Option D. Data insufficient to comment: The calculated RR of 1 provides a clear interpretation, so the data is sufficient to comment on the association.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a cohort study, a risk ratio (RR) of 1 indicates no association between the exposure factor and the disease outcome.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is an AR murmur likely to be heard? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ventricular diastole


Aortic regurgitation (AR) murmurs are classic early diastolic murmurs heard during ventricular diastole, when blood flows back into the left ventricle from the aorta.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Ventricular ejection: Associated with systolic murmurs.
 

Option B. Throughout cardiac cycle: Associated with continuous murmurs, like in PDA.
 

Option C. Isovolumetric contraction: Not typically associated with murmurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic regurgitation murmurs are heard during ventricular diastole

questions.text: Identify the wrongly marked structure in the diagram? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C-Hypothalamus

 

The image shows the midsagittal section of the brain. The wrongly marked structure is C-hypothalamus. The structure marked as C corresponds to the thalamus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus Callosum: It's a large white matter structure found deep within the brain, lying superiorly to the thalamus and under the cortex. It connects the two cerebral hemispheres.

 

  • The primary purpose of the corpus callosum is to integrate motor, sensory, and cognitive performances between the cerebral cortex on one side of the brain to the same region on the other side. Essentially, it allows for communication between the two hemispheres of the brain.

 

Option C. Pituitary Gland: It is a pea-sized structure that's located at the base of the brain, right below the hypothalamus.

 

  • Often referred to as the "master gland," the pituitary gland secretes hormones that control several other endocrine glands. It has an anterior and posterior portion, each releasing specific hormones. These hormones regulate various physiological processes, including growth, reproductive cycles, and stress response.

 

Option D. Cerebellum: Located at the ventral part of the brain, below the occipital lobes and posterior to the brainstem.

 

  • The cerebellum is primarily responsible for coordination and fine-tuning of motor movements. It also plays roles in posture and balance, and there is increasing evidence that it's involved in cognitive functions and emotion regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothalamus is situated at the base of the brain, just below the thalamus and right above the pituitary gland. This plays a crucial role in many important functions, including releasing hormones, regulating body temperature, maintaining daily physiological cycles, controlling appetite, managing of sexual behavior, and responding to the feeling of being full (eating).

choices.text: Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

questions.text: A patient with CKD with refractory hypertension is brought to the casualty with dizziness. His BP was found to be 200/120 mmHg. His BUN was 50 mg/dl and creatinine was 3 mg/dl. Potassium was 6 mEq/L. Which of the following is an indication of emergency hemodialysis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated in several critical conditions commonly remembered with the mnemonic AEIOU:

 

  1. Acidosis: Severe metabolic acidosis that is not responsive to standard medical therapy, particularly when the pH is less than 7.1.
  2. Electrolyte imbalance: Severe hyperkalemia, especially when potassium levels are more than 6.5 mEq/L, rapidly rising, or refractory to medical management.
  3. Intoxications: With dialyzable drugs.
  4. Overload: Volume overload state, such as diuretic-resistant pulmonary edema, particularly when oxygen requirements are increasing.
  5. Uremia: Uremic complications such as pericarditis or encephalopathy, which are urgent indications due to the risk of tamponade or severe cognitive impairment.

 

In this patient, severe acidosis, alongside elevated BUN and creatinine, is a strong indication for emergency hemodialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertension: Hypertension alone, even when severe, is not an immediate indication for emergency hemodialysis

 

Option C. Potassium level of 6 mEq/L: While elevated, a potassium level of 6 mEq/L by itself is not enough to indicate emergency dialysis unless it is rapidly rising or refractory to treatment. Typically, levels above 6.5 mEq/L are considered more critical.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: This is not an indication for emergency hemodialysis. Instead, metabolic acidosis, especially when severe and refractory to treatment, is a more significant concern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated for severe acidosis, refractory hyperkalemia, volume overload, intoxications, and uremic complications. Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine is a critical indication for initiating emergency hemodialysis.

questions.text: A healthcare professional is reviewing vaccine protocols to update patient information materials. In doing so, she focuses on the type of vaccine used for diphtheria prevention. Which option correctly describes the type of diphtheria vaccine? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Toxoid

 

  • The diphtheria vaccine is a toxoid vaccine, which involves the use of toxins produced by the bacterium that causes the disease.
  • These toxins are chemically inactivated to form toxoids, which are safe for use in vaccines but still capable of eliciting a strong immune response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of vaccine -

questions.text: Osborn waves in ECG are seen in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hypothermia

 

Osborn waves, also known as J-waves, are characteristic findings on an ECG that are typically associated with hypothermia. These waves appear as a positive deflection at the J point (the junction between the end of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST segment) and are most evident in moderate to severe cases of hypothermia. The appearance of Osborn waves is thought to be caused by a disparity in the action potential durations between the epicardial and endocardial surfaces of the heart during ventricular repolarization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: This condition does not typically cause Osborn waves. Instead, hypothyroidism can lead to other ECG changes such as bradycardia, low voltage, and possibly prolonged QT interval.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: This typically leads to a prolonged QT interval but does not cause Osborn waves.

 

Option D. Hypokalemia: While hypokalemia can cause significant ECG changes, including U waves, flattened T waves, and ST depression, it is not associated with Osborn waves.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

J-wave or Osborn wave is seen in cases of moderate or severe hypothermia due to increase in the epicardial potassium current relative to that of endocardium during ventricular repolarization.

questions.text: Match the given cellular components with their respective marker enzymes?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C

 

The correct matches of cellular components with their marker enzymes are:

 

  1. Mitochondria - ATP synthase (D): ATP synthase is a key enzyme in the mitochondria involved in the synthesis of ATP, making it a marker enzyme for this organelle.
  2. Peroxisomes - Catalase (A): Catalase is an enzyme found in peroxisomes that helps in the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide, making it a characteristic marker for peroxisomes.
  3. Golgi complex - Galactosyl transferase (B): Galactosyl transferase is involved in the glycosylation processes in the Golgi complex, serving as a marker enzyme for this organelle.
  4. Endoplasmic reticulum - Glucose-6-phosphatase (C): Glucose-6-phosphatase is found in the endoplasmic reticulum and is involved in glucose metabolism, making it a marker enzyme for this structure.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which muscle is not involved in the inversion of foot? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Peroneus longus

 

The peroneus longus is a muscle of the lateral compartment of the leg. It originates from the head and upper two-thirds of the fibula, and it has a long tendon that wraps behind the lateral malleolus and extends to the medial side of the foot, inserting into the base of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform. When the peroneus longus contracts, it everts the foot and also plantarflexes the ankle. Therefore, the peroneus longus is not involved in the inversion of the foot.

 

Inversion of the foot is a movement in which the medial border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces medially.

 

  • Tibialis anterior - Dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot
  • Tibialis posterior - Plantar flexion and inversion of the foot
  • Extensor hallucis longs - Extension of the great toe, dorsiflexion of the foot, and inversion of the foot (minimal action)

 

Eversion of the foot is a movement where the lateral border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces laterally.

 

  • Peroneus longus, peroneus brevis, and peroneus tertius are the muscles involved.

 

These movements take place, mainly at the talocalcaneal and the talocalcaneonavicular joints, and partly at the transverse tarsal joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis anterior: The tibialis anterior is a muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. It originates from the lateral surface of the tibia and inserts into the medial cuneiform and first metatarsal bones of the foot. When this muscle contracts, it dorsiflexes the ankle (pulls the foot upwards, towards the shin) and inverts the foot. Therefore, the tibialis anterior plays a role in foot inversion.

 

Option B. Tibialis posterior: The tibialis posterior is located in the deep compartment of the leg. It originates from the posterior surfaces of the tibia and fibula and inserts into various bones in the foot, including the navicular, cuneiforms, and metatarsals. When the tibialis posterior contracts, it plantarflexes the ankle (points the foot downward) and also inverts the foot. Like the tibialis anterior, the tibialis posterior is involved in foot inversion.

 

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: The extensor hallucis longus is another muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. It originates from the anterior surface of the fibula and the interosseous membrane and inserts into the distal phalanx of the big toe. Its primary action is to dorsiflex the big toe. While it plays a role in dorsiflexion of the ankle, its contribution to inversion or eversion is minimal compared to the other muscles listed. However, it can assist in inversion to a minor extent when combined with other inverters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peroneus longus muscle is not involved in the inversion of the foot. It causes eversion and plantar flexion.

 

The transverse tarsal joint and the talocalcaneal and talocalcaneonavicular joints also play a role in inversion and eversion movements

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder presents to the psychiatric clinic for follow-up. She was recently hospitalized for a severe manic episode and is now on lithium therapy. The psychiatrist explains the importance of maintaining appropriate serum lithium levels to ensure therapeutic efficacy while minimizing toxicity. The patient is advised to undergo regular serum level monitoring due to lithium’s narrow therapeutic window. What is the recommended therapeutic serum lithium level range for both acute attacks of mania and long-term maintenance?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL


Lithium is commonly used for the treatment of bipolar disorder, particularly during acute manic episodes and for long-term maintenance to prevent relapses. It has a narrow therapeutic window, requiring careful serum level monitoring to avoid toxicity. The general therapeutic range for lithium is 0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL. For acute manic episodes, the target serum lithium level typically falls between 1.0 to 1.2 mEq/dL, whereas long-term maintenance levels are ideally maintained between 0.4 to 0.8 mEq/dL. However, the broader range of 0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL encompasses the acceptable levels during different phases of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:


The therapeutic serum lithium level range is 0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL, which covers the needs for both acute manic episodes and long-term maintenance. Regular monitoring is essential due to lithium's narrow therapeutic window and potential toxicity at higher levels.

questions.text:
Which of the following types of headaches requires further evaluation? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Headache for > 4 hours
  2. Worst headache of life
  3. New-onset progressive headache
  4. Headache with blurring of vision
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) 2, 3, 4

 

Certain types of headaches can be indicative of serious underlying conditions and thus require further evaluation to rule out life-threatening or severe pathologies:

 

2. Worst headache of life: This is a classic description of a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which is a medical emergency. Patients experiencing this type of headache require immediate medical attention and thorough investigation, typically involving neuroimaging.

 

3. New-onset progressive headache: Progressive headaches, especially those that are new in onset and occur in adults, raise concern for potential serious conditions such as brain tumors or other intracranial pathologies. These headaches warrant detailed medical evaluation.

 

4. Headache with blurring of vision: This symptom combination suggests possible increased intracranial pressure, which can be associated with conditions like papilledema or optic neuritis. Such cases need prompt assessment to determine the cause and appropriate management.

 

Other Option:

 

1. Headache for > 4 hours: While a headache lasting more than four hours can be distressing, it is not necessarily indicative of a severe underlying condition. Such headaches could be primary headaches like tension-type headaches or migraines, which often do not require immediate further evaluation unless they have other alarming features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Headaches described as the "worst headache of life," new-onset progressive headaches, and headaches accompanied by blurring of vision require further medical evaluation to rule out serious conditions.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a patient who has paronychia on their index finger and is also showing a reddish streak on their forearm, as depicted in the image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amoxiclav

 

  • The above image depicts paronychia associated with a reddish erythematous streak-like lesion on the hand suggestive of paronychia associated with lymphangitis, which is managed by elevating the affected extremity and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • A broad-spectrum antibiotic like Amoxiclav is appropriate for covering both the pathogens commonly responsible for the initial localized infection and the secondary systemic spread.

 

Acute paronychia:

 

It is infection of the nail fold which is characterized by inflammation, swelling and abscess formation.

Most common causative organism - Staphylococcus aureus
 

Diagnosis - Clinical

 

Management - Systemic antibiotics may be needed for deep infections.

 

Treatment of Acute paronychia -

 

  • Abscesses - Incised and drained (Abscess is often opened by pushing the nail fold away from the nail plate).
     
  • Antibiotics - Semisynthetic penicillin/cephalosporin with excellent anti-staphylococcal orally.

 

Complications - Osteitis and amputation.

 

Lymphangitis: represents acute inflammation elicited by the spread of bacterial infections into lymphatics with group A beta haemolytic streptococci being the most common causative agent.

 

Clinical features: Lymphangitis manifests as red painful subcutaneous streaks & painful enlargement of the draining lymph nodes (lymphadenitis). It is managed by elevating the affected extremity & broad spectrum antibiotics.

 

Chronic paronychia:

 

  • Most common causative organism - Candida albicans.
  • Candidal paronychia is most common in individuals who have their hands in water for a great deal of time.
  • Given recent evidence that Candida colonization may play a secondary role in chronic paronychia, with the primary insult being skin barrier breakdown resulting from wet work and possible contact dermatitis, a role for topical corticosteroids has been demonstrated.
  • Treatment - Topical antifungals & Topical corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metronidazole: Primarily effective against anaerobic bacteria and certain protozoa. While useful in skin and soft tissue infections involving anaerobes, it is not the first-line treatment for paronychia or lymphangitis which typically involve aerobic gram-positive cocci.

 

Option C. Amikacin: A powerful aminoglycoside antibiotic used primarily for severe, hospital-acquired infections with multi-drug resistant bacteria. It is not typically used for initial treatment of common skin infections due to its potential for causing significant side effects, including nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

 

Option D. Norfloxacin: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic used primarily for gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections. While it has broad-spectrum activity, it is generally not the first choice for skin infections and is less effective against gram-positive organisms commonly causing skin infections.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Combination antibiotic Amoxiclav is indicated for the treatment of paronychia complicated by lymphangitis due to its broad-spectrum activity against both Gram-positive and resistant bacteria.

questions.text: Match the following with the respective ages of fusion: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

Ages of Fusion:

 

  1. Medial end of clavicle:
    • Age of Fusion: 21-25 years
    • Description: The medial end of the clavicle is one of the last bones to complete its growth and fusion, typically fusing between 21 and 25 years of age.
  2. Sacrum as a single bone:
    • Age of Fusion: 22-25 years
    • Description: The sacral vertebrae fuse to form a single sacrum typically between 22 and 25 years of age.
  3. Crista scapulae:
    • Age of Fusion: 50 years
    • Description: The crista scapulae, or the scapular spine, continues to undergo changes and does not completely fuse until around 50 years of age.

  4. Lambdoid suture:

    • Age of Fusion: 45 years
    • Description: The lambdoid suture, located at the back of the skull, typically fuses around 45 years of age.

     

Educational Objective:

 

The age of fusion are:

questions.text: A public health researcher is studying the prevalence of a disease among school-aged children in a suburban town across two separate periods during the monsoon season. Two unpaired cohorts of children are observed: one from June to July and another from August to September. To compare the prevalence rates between these two cohorts, which statistical test is most appropriate? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi square

 

  • Chi-square test can be implemented in this given scenario.
  • The data is expressed as proportion of children affected by the disease in various months.
  • It is a qualitative variable as we assess the proportion of children who are affected by the disease and those who are not affected by the disease. The chi-square test can be used to compare two or more groups.

 

Chi square: Non parametric test used for comparing percentage, proportions & fractions in two or more different group of individuals. 

 

Example: Three-fourth of MBBS students in a class are underweight whereas another class has two thirds anaemic; test of significance to be used is Chi-square test

 

Fischer’s test: Is a variant of Chi-square test when sample size is < 30

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paired t test: Parametric test which is used to compare means (+ SD) in paired data (in same group of individuals before and after an intervention)

 

  • Example: Mean serum albumin level of dengue patients before treatment was 3.6 g/dL and after treatment was 3.2 g/dL; Comparison of mean levels can be done by Paired Student’s t-test (Unpaired Student’s t-test is for comparing means (+ SD) in two different group of individuals - Example: Mean Hb level of anemia patients was 9.6 g/dL and those of hookworm patients was 7.2 g/dL; Comparison of mean levels can be done by Unpaired Student’s t-test; Z - test: Is a variant of student’s t-test which is used when sample size is > 30)

 

Option C. Wilcoxon test: Non parametric test used for comparing percentage, proportions & fractions in matched paired data

 

  • Wilcoxon (rank sum) test: Comparing percentage, proportions & fractions in two unpaired samples
  • Mann-Whitney (Wilcoxon) test:
    • MWW is same as Wilcoxon (rank sum) test
    • Is used for assessing whether two set of observations come from same distribution (if 2 independent ‘nonpaired’ samples come from the same population)
    • ‘MWW is analogous to parametric two-sample t-test’ on the data after ranking over the combined samples
    • MWW requires calculation of ‘U statistic’.

 

Option D. ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) (F-test/F-ratio): Parametric test used to compare means (+ SD) in more than two different group of individuals

 

  • Example: Mean weight of students in class A is 50 kg, those of class B is 44.6 kg and those of class C is 52.7 kg; Comparison of mean weights can be done by ANOVA test.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the picture given below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

The structure marked "A" is the levator ani muscle which is the component of pelvic diaphragm.

 

Other structures marked in the above image are:

 

B: External anal sphincter

C: Obturator internus

D: Perianal fascia

 

Pelvic diaphragm -

 

The pelvic diaphragm is the muscular part of the pelvic floor. It connects to the pelvic wall on both sides, between the greater and lesser sciatic foramen. The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the levator ani and coccyges muscles, which define the lower limit of the true pelvis.

 

 

Pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, and puborectalis combine to form Levator ani. The muscles in both sexes blend together posterior to the vagina and around the anus. The form in which the anococcygeal body attaches to the coccyx posterior to the anal aperture.

 

Urogenital hiatus is present anteriorly separating the muscles. This allows the urethra and vagina to pass through. Levator ani reinforces the external anal sphincter. In women, it functions as the vaginal sphincter.

 

The coccyges muscles are triangular in shape and form the posterior part of the pelvic diaphragm, one on each side. The apices are attached to the ischial spine tips. The bases connect to the coccyx and sacrum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphincter Ani Externus (External Anal Sphincter): This is a circular muscle that surrounds the anus. It's located below the level of the levator ani. It is innervated by the pudendal nerve, allowing for voluntary control over defecation.

 

Option C. Obturator Muscle: This term often refers to two muscles - obturator externus and obturator internus. They are situated on either side of the obturator membrane in the pelvis. Obturator Externus: Obturator nerve and Obturator Internus: Nerve to obturator internus (a branch of the sacral plexus).

 

Option D. Perianal Fascia: The perianal fascia is not a muscle but is the connective tissue located in the perianal region, around the anus. It's part of the deeper layers of the skin in this region.  It's associated with various potential spaces that can become sites of abscess formation if there's an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The levator ani is the principal muscle of the pelvic floor and is composed of three parts: the puborectalis, the pubococcygeus, and the iliococcygeus. It is primarily innervated by the pudendal nerve and the S4 nerve root.

questions.text: The patient developed pigmentation on the nose after experiencing fever and joint pain, which appeared shortly after taking NSAIDs as shown below. What would be the likely diagnosis in this case? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chikungunya

 

  • The patient's medical history is indicative of a potential diagnosis of Chikungunya (CKG) infection.
  • Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral illness presenting with fever, joint pain, and potential rash.

 

 

Fig: Nose pigmentation

 

IMAGE DEPICTING CHIK SIGN

 

  • It can cause skin hyperpigmentation, especially on the nose and cheeks, known as the "Chik sign."
  • The "Chik sign" is distinctive to Chikungunya and is not usually seen with other viral infections.
  • The nose pigmentation may last three to six months post-infection, aiding in clinical and retrospective diagnosis.
  • This pigmentation pattern serves as a clinical marker for Chikungunya infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melasma:

 

Typically presents as symmetric brown patches on the face, especially the cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip as shown in the image below.

 

 

It is often triggered by sun exposure or hormonal changes, such as pregnancy or use of oral contraceptives.

 

Option B. Fixed drug eruption (FDE):

 

  • It is a type of allergic reaction to medications. It presents as well-demarcated, round, or oval patches of redness and swelling that can later become brown.
  • However, FDEs are typically recurrent in the same location when the offending drug is taken again, and the presentation isn't specifically associated with the symptoms described.

 

Option C. Lichen planus:

 

  • Lichen planus is an inflammatory condition that affects the skin and mucous membranes, presenting as itchy, purple, polygonal, flat-topped papules.
  • It is not usually associated with the intake of NSAIDs and the subsequent appearance of pigmented lesions in the described manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of fever, body ache, and joint pain, followed by the development of brownish pigmentation on the nose, Chikungunya is the probable diagnosis, as it can present with persistent joint pain and hyperpigmentation, particularly in regions where the virus is endemic.

questions.text: The structures marked in the image below are found in the epithelial lining of all of the following sites, except? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epididymis

 

The picture depicts an arrow mark pointing in the direction of the cilia. All of the structures listed as choices have ciliated lining epithelia, with the exception of the epididymis, which has pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia, that’s play a role in sperm maturation and storage.

 

The given image is a histological section of the epididymis showing the pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia.

 

 

Cilia are minute hair-like projections, while stereocilia are very long, thick microvilli measuring about 5-10 um in length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oviduct (Fallopian Tube): The oviduct, also known as the Fallopian tube, is a part of the female reproductive system. It contains ciliated epithelium, which helps in the transport of the egg from the ovary to the uterus. The cilia in the oviduct assist in moving the egg and help in the fertilization process.

 

Option C. Bronchi: The bronchi are part of the respiratory system and are responsible for conducting air to and from the lungs. They contain ciliated epithelium to help move mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Ependyma : it is a type of neuroglial cell that lines the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. It contains ciliated epithelium, which assists in the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciliated epithelium:

 

  • The epithelium bears cilia, which moves in a coordinated fashion, and help in the movement of the mucus, or propel the movement of any other structures such as ova or spermatozoa.
  • The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.
  • The pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is seen in the trachea and in large bronchi.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defect in which of the following cell?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type 2 pneumocytes

 

One of the most characteristic findings in respiratory distress syndrome is failure of the respiratory epithelium to secrete adequate quantities of surfactant, a substance normally secreted into the alveoli that decreases the surface tension of the alveolar fluid, therefore allowing the alveoli to open easily during inspiration.

 

The surfactant-secreting cells are type II alveolar epithelial cells.

 

Production of the surfactant begins by week 20-24. It appears in the amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation. Mature levels of the pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 weeks of gestation.

 

Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase production of surfactant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 pneumocytes: Incorrect because although Type 1 pneumocytes cover a large surface area of the alveoli and are involved in the gas exchange process, they do not produce surfactant. The defect in Type 1 pneumocytes generally leads to issues with the structural integrity of the alveolar walls, not surfactant deficiency.

 

Option C. Alveolar capillary endothelial cells: Incorrect as these cells line the alveolar capillaries and are involved in the blood-air barrier for gas exchange. Defects in these cells can lead to issues like pulmonary edema but are not directly related to surfactant production or respiratory distress syndrome due to surfactant deficiency.

 

Option D. Bronchial mucosal epithelial cells: Incorrect because these cells line the bronchial passages and are primarily involved in mucous production and the removal of particulates and pathogens from inhaled air. They are not involved in surfactant production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, is commonly due to insufficient surfactant production by Type 2 pneumocytes. This deficiency impedes the lungs' ability to expand properly, leading to respiratory distress. Management often includes the administration of exogenous surfactant and supportive care to enhance lung function until the infant's own cells can produce adequate surfactant.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has a lesion over the face as shown below. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BCC (Basal cell carcinoma)

 

The given history with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders points to a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer, especially in older individuals with sun exposure. It often appears as a pearly or waxy bump with central depression, which can bleed easily. Itching is also a common symptom associated with BCC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatofibrosarcoma: Dermatofibrosarcoma is a rare, slow-growing soft tissue tumor that typically presents as a painless, raised, flesh-colored or brownish lesion. It does not commonly cause bleeding or itching.

 

 

Option B. Marjolin's Ulcer: Marjolin's ulcer refers to a malignant transformation of a chronic non-healing wound, scar, or ulcer. It is often associated with long-standing inflammation or trauma. While it can present with bleeding, it typically doesn't cause itching as a primary symptom.

 

 

Option D. Naevus: A nevus, commonly known as a mole, is a benign skin lesion. While moles can occasionally be itchy, they do not usually cause bleeding unless they are irritated or traumatized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma is an epithelial tumor that arises from basal cells layer of epidermis. It is the most common type of skin cancer. Most commonly seen over the face, above the line joining corner of the mouth, and lobule of the ear. Clinically it can present either as nodular or pigmented BCC. Features of nodular BCC are:

 

  1. Small, slowly growing pearly nodule
  2. Tortuous telangiectatic vessels on the surface
  3. Rolled borders
  4. Central crusting

 

The occasional presence of melanin in the nodular variant of BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

questions.text: An infant (given below in the image) presents to ophthalmology OPD with lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Congenital Glaucoma

 

Congenital Glaucoma is a rare condition that can occur in babies and young children. It's caused by an abnormal development of the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure, which can damage the optic nerve. Symptoms can include photophobia, excessive tearing (lacrimation), and cloudy, enlarged corneas. Given the symptoms  described, congenital glaucoma is a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS): This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans. While MPS can affect the eyes, leading to problems like corneal clouding and glaucoma, the key symptoms often include developmental delay, skeletal and joint abnormalities, and coarse facial features. Eye-related symptoms are typically not the first presenting symptoms in MPS.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This refers to a clouding of the lens of the eye that is present at birth. Congenital cataracts can cause a variety of symptoms including a noticeable white, grey, or yellow spot in the pupil, nystagmus (uncontrolled eye movements), and yes, potentially photophobia. However, lacrimation (excessive tearing) is not a typical symptom of cataracts.

 

Option D. Ophthalmia Neonatorum: This condition is a form of conjunctivitis that occurs in newborns. Typically, it's caused by bacteria acquired during passage through the birth canal from an infected mother. The primary symptoms include redness of the eyes, swelling of the eyelids, and discharge, which may be watery or pus-like. Photophobia can be a symptom, but it's not as common as in some other conditions like congenital glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Glaucoma should be suspected in infants presenting with photophobia, excessive tearing, and cloudy, enlarged corneas, as it is due to the abnormal development of the eye's drainage system leading to increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies is associated with sexual maturation defect and hypogonadism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zn (Zinc)

 

Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a critical role in numerous biological functions, including growth, immune function, and reproduction. Zinc deficiency is associated with several clinical manifestations, among which hypogonadism and delayed sexual maturation are prominent. Hypogonadism refers to a condition where the body does not produce enough sex hormones, which can lead to delayed puberty, underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics, and infertility.

 

The deficiency of zinc impairs the normal functioning of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, leading to decreased production of testosterone in males and estrogen in females. This hormonal imbalance is directly linked to the symptoms of sexual maturation defects observed in zinc-deficient individuals.

 

Zinc also plays a significant role in wound healing, immune function, and DNA synthesis. Its deficiency can lead to delayed wound healing, impaired immune response, and chronic diarrhea, further exacerbating the clinical picture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selenium: Selenium deficiency is primarily associated with oxidative stress-related conditions, such as Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a type of osteoarthropathy). It is not typically associated with hypogonadism or sexual maturation defects.

 

Option C. Cu (Copper): Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, neutropenia, and neurological issues but is not linked with hypogonadism or delayed sexual maturation. Copper is involved in iron metabolism and the functioning of several enzymes but does not directly impact the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.

 

Option D. Iron: Iron deficiency is well-known for causing anemia, particularly microcytic hypochromic anemia, and can lead to symptoms such as fatigue and weakness. While severe iron deficiency can impact overall growth and development, it is not specifically associated with hypogonadism or sexual maturation defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency is directly linked to hypogonadism and delayed sexual maturation, along with other symptoms such as impaired wound healing, decreased immunity, and chronic diarrhea. Recognizing and correcting zinc deficiency is crucial for preventing these clinical outcomes.

choices.text: High up in the false pelvis

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady nearing her due date has been admitted following regular contractions. The resident doctor did an examination and told the intern that the head is at +1 station. Where is the exact position of head? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Just below ischial spine

 

In obstetrics, the station of the fetal head during labor is measured relative to the ischial spines of the maternal pelvis. The ischial spines are bony landmarks that serve as reference points.

 

  • 0 Station: The presenting part of the fetus is at the level of the ischial spines.
  • Positive Stations (+1 to +5): These indicate the presenting part is below the ischial spines. For example, +1 station means the presenting part is 1 cm below the ischial spines.
  • Negative Stations (-1 to -5): These indicate the presenting part is above the ischial spines.

 

At +1 station, the fetal head is just below the ischial spine by 1 cm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. At the perineum: This would indicate a more advanced station, such as +4 or +5.

 

Option C. Just above the ischial spine: This would be a negative station (e.g., -1 or -2).

 

Option D. High up in the false pelvis: This would correspond to a much higher, negative station.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the station of the head is described during a vaginal exam, it is with respect to the ischial spine:

 

  • The ischial spine is taken as 0 station.
  • Anything above the ischial spine is denoted as a negative station (-).
  • Anything below the ischial spine is denoted as a positive station (+).

 

Ref: Page no 153, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Korsakoff syndrome is primarily associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.
Patients with Korsakoff syndrome typically have intact recent memory but impaired long-term recall.
Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by anterograde amnesia and confabulation.
Korsakoff syndrome predominantly affects motor and sensory functions.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a long history of alcohol misuse presents to the clinic with severe memory disturbances. The patient is previously diagnosed with Korsakoff syndrome. Which of the following statements is true regarding Korsakoff syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by anterograde amnesia and confabulation.

 


Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by severe thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, most commonly associated with chronic alcohol misuse. It is characterized by anterograde amnesia, where patients have difficulty forming new memories, and confabulation, a common feature where patients unconsciously fabricate information to fill in memory gaps. Retrograde amnesia affecting older memories can also be present. The condition often follows Wernicke’s encephalopathy and requires prompt thiamine replacement and alcohol cessation for management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Korsakoff syndrome is primarily associated with vitamin B12 deficiency: This statement is incorrect. Korsakoff syndrome is caused by a deficiency in thiamine (vitamin B1), not vitamin B12. Thiamine deficiency disrupts brain function and can lead to this chronic memory disorder.

 

Option B. Patients with Korsakoff syndrome typically have intact recent memory but impaired long-term recall: This is incorrect because Korsakoff syndrome primarily affects the ability to form new memories (anterograde amnesia), while long-term memories from before the onset of the disorder are often preserved.

 

Option D. Korsakoff syndrome predominantly affects motor and sensory functions: This statement is incorrect. Korsakoff syndrome mainly affects memory, particularly short-term memory, without significant motor or sensory deficits.

 

Educational Objective:


Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by thiamine deficiency, often linked to alcohol misuse. It is characterized by anterograde amnesia and confabulation, with patients unable to form new memories and frequently fabricating information to fill memory gaps.

questions.text: A known patient of tuberculosis, on INH for the past 3 months complains of numbness, tingling and burning sensation in all the extremities. What could be vitamin deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

This is the correct answer. Isoniazid (INH) can lead to a deficiency in Vitamin B6. Peripheral neuropathy, which includes symptoms like numbness, tingling, and burning sensations in the extremities, is a common side effect of Vitamin B6 deficiency. Therefore, the patient's symptoms are likely a result of this deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin) Deficiency: Vitamin B12 deficiency can also cause neuropathy and neurological symptoms, but it's less likely to be associated with INH use specifically. However, it's essential to consider Vitamin B12 levels in tuberculosis patients, as they may have dietary restrictions or other factors that could lead to this deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) Deficiency: Vitamin B1 deficiency can cause a condition called beriberi, which can include neurological symptoms. However, INH is not known to directly cause Vitamin B1 deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin) Deficiency: Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which includes skin issues and neurological symptoms. INH can indirectly affect niacin levels, but it's not a common cause of niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid inhibits pyridoxal phosphokinase which is required for synthesis of biologically active form of pyridoxine (B6) i.e. pyridoxal phosphate. Thus, isoniazid inhibits the formation of the active form of B6.
  • As Vit. B6 (PLP) is required for niacin (B3) synthesis from tryptophan, hence isoniazid therapy also causes Niacin deficiency.
  • In this question, best answer to mark is B6 as INH directly inhibits B6 formation.

 

Reference: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-371

questions.text: After the administration of phenylephrine, the depicted images reveal an observed alteration. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nodular episcleritis

 

Upon the application of phenylephrine, the superficial episcleral vessels lose their color, a phenomenon known as blanching. As a result, the likely conclusion is nodular episcleritis.

 

2.5% phenylephrine proves valuable in distinguishing between episcleritis and scleritis. This distinction arises from the fact that the vessels within the episclera lie close to the surface, making them susceptible to blanching. In contrast, in cases of scleritis, these vessels do not undergo such a color change.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular Scleritis: Scleritis involves deeper layers of the eye and is typically more painful. Vessels in scleritis do not blanch with phenylephrine due to their depth and the severity of inflammation.

 

Option C. Tenon's Cyst: This refers to a cystic lesion involving Tenon's capsule, not typically associated with the superficial vascular changes seen in episcleritis.

 

Option D. Nodular Phlycten: This is a small, nodular inflammatory lesion usually at the corneal limbus, often related to an immune response to bacterial proteins, particularly from staphylococcal or tubercular origins, not showing the same response to phenylephrine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episcleritis can typically be diagnosed based on its clinical appearance and response to phenylephrine. The ability of phenylephrine to cause blanching of the inflamed episcleral vessels is a useful diagnostic tool, helping to differentiate episcleritis from more serious conditions like scleritis, where the inflammation involves deeper tissues and the vessels do not blanch.

choices.text: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor to prevent post-partum hemorrhage? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gentle massage of uterus

 

AMTSL

 

Purpose: To prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), a major cause of maternal death.

 

  1. Give a uterotonic drug
    • Oxytocin 10 IU IM immediately after the birth of the baby
    • This helps the uterus contract and reduce bleeding
  2. Controlled Cord Traction (CCT)
    • Gently pull the umbilical cord while supporting the uterus to help deliver the placenta
    • Only if trained and placenta is ready to come
  3. Intermittent uterine tone assessment

 

Delayed cord clamping

 

  • Wait 1–3 minutes before clamping the umbilical cord
  • Improves baby’s iron stores and reduces anemia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterotonic within 1 minute of delivery: This is a critical step in AMTSL to prevent PPH by promoting uterine contractions.

 

Option B. Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord: Delayed cord clamping (after 1 to 3 minutes) is recommended for all births to enhance neonatal outcomes

 

Option D. Controlled cord traction: This is a part of AMTSL to aid in the delivery of the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The active management of the third stage of labor includes the administration of a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and assessing uterine tone rather than sustained uterine massage for all women who have received a uterotonic.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/120082/WHO_RHR_14.20_eng.pdf?sequence=1

questions.text:
The fibres of the internal oblique muscle and transversus abdominus muscle contribute to which boundaries of the inguinal canal walls? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Anterior wall
  2. Roof
  3. Floor
  4. Posterior wall
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ii and iv

 

 

 

The inguinal canal is an important structure in the anterior abdominal wall, with specific boundaries formed by different layers of muscles and fascia. The internal oblique is present in the lateral 1/3rd of anterior wall but transverse abdominis does not contribute to the anterior wall at all.

 

ii. Roof: The fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, along with their conjoint tendon, form the roof of the inguinal canal.

 

iv. Posterior wall: The conjoint tendon, formed by the joining of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, also contributes to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

i. Anterior wall: The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is primarily formed by the external oblique aponeurosis, along with skin and superficial fascia. The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles do not contribute to the anterior wall.

 

iii. Floor: The floor of the inguinal canal is formed by the inguinal ligament, not by the internal oblique or transversus abdominis muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles contribute to the roof and posterior wall of the inguinal canal through their conjoint tendon.

questions.text: A nursing assistant posted in the obstetric care unit was asked to plot a partograph to monitor the progress of labour. After how much dilatation of the cervix, should she start plotting the graph? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4cm

 

  • In the WHO modified partograph, labor ((Cervical dilatation vs time)  is plotted on a graph and analysis includes use of action lines and alert lines.
  • In the WHO modified partograph, the plotting starts in active phase (4cm)
  • The alert line is plotted at a cervical dilatation rate of 1cm/h
  • The action line is plotted 4h to the right of the alert line
  •  The 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • The WHO modified partograph has now been replaced by the WHO labor care guide where the new definition of active labor is 5 cm so when answering a question read carefully what is asked – WHO modified partograph or WHO Labor care guide

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plotting on the partograph should start at 4 cm cervical dilatation during the active phase of labor.

 

Ref: Page no 152, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 7th edition

choices.text: Parkinson Disease
Alzheimer's disease

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is most commonly associated with Down's syndrome: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alzheimer’s disease

 

Individuals with Down’s syndrome are at a significantly higher risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease, often in their 30s and 40s, due to the presence of three copies of chromosome 21, which contains the APP gene involved in the production of amyloid precursor protein—a key factor in Alzheimer’s pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parkinson Disease: Not specifically associated with Down's syndrome.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: No significant correlation between Down's syndrome and schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Huntington's Disease: No direct association with Down's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conditions most commonly associated with Down's syndrome:

 

  • Congenital heart disease (in about 35% of cases)
  • Gastrointestinal anomalies (in about 10%)
  • Chronic serous otitis media (in >50%)
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alzheimer's disease (in the 30's and 40's)
  • Epilepsy (in about 10%)
  • Ocular disorders
  • Reduced fertility
  • Reduced life span (Often due to complications like infections)

choices.text: Tingling and numbness of hands and feet

questions.text: Amongst the options given below, which of these are not seen in cocaine poisoning? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Constricted pupils and bradycardia

 

Dilated pupils and tachycardia is seen with cocaine ingestion as it is a sympathomimetic (stimulant).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tingling and numbness of hands and feet: This is a common symptom due to the neurological effects of cocaine.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Cocaine causes vasoconstriction and increased heart rate, leading to hypertension.

 

Option D. Hyperthermia: Increased body temperature is a common finding due to excessive sympathetic stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of cocaine intoxication:

 

  • Early features – Stage of excitement:
  • Dry mouth, dysphagia, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, dilated pupils, and increased temperature followed by convulsions, hallucinations, tingling, and numbness in the hands and feet.
  • Late features – Stage of depression – Respiration is depressed, excessive sweating, collapse, convulsions, and death.
  • Magnan’s symptoms / Cocaine bugs - Chronic cocaine users may have the feeling of insects crawling on their skin or the presence of grains of sand under the skin.
  • Ulceration of nasal septum seen due to sniffing cocaine in chronic abuse

questions.text: All among the following are ionizing radiations except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. MRI


MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) does not use ionizing radiation. Instead, it employs strong magnetic fields and radio waves to generate images of the organs and structures inside the body. This makes MRI an important diagnostic tool, particularly useful for imaging soft tissues without the risks associated with ionizing radiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha particles: These are a type of ionizing radiation consisting of helium nuclei and are known to be highly ionizing but with low penetration power.

 

Option B. Gamma rays: Gamma rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation, like X-rays, but typically have even higher energy levels and are certainly ionizing, capable of penetrating deep into biological tissues and causing ionization.

 

Option D. X-rays: X-rays are a well-known form of electromagnetic ionizing radiation used widely in medical imaging to view the structure of the body, particularly bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ionizing Radiation

questions.text: A female working in the matchbox factory presents to the dentist with loose teeth, foul smelling discharge, sinuses and fistulae around mouth and disfigurement of the jaw as shown in the picture below. What is the causative agent for this condition? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Phosphorus  

 

  • The disease mentioned above is phosphorus necrosis of the jaw, commonly called as 'phossy jaw'.
  • It is caused due to exposure to white phosphorus during the manufacture of matches. They were made by dipping the match ends into a mixture containing white phosphorus.
  • Features of phossy jaw- Osteomyelitis and necrosis of the jaw, with foul-smelling pus discharging multiple sinuses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bromine: Bromine exposure does not cause the described condition.

 

Option B. Antimony: Antimony poisoning can cause various health issues but is not known to cause phossy jaw.

 

Option C. Fluorine: Fluorine toxicity can cause skeletal and dental fluorosis but does not cause the specific symptoms of phossy jaw.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phossy jaw is caused by exposure to white phosphorus, leading to osteomyelitis, necrosis of the jaw, foul-smelling discharge, and significant disfigurement.

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks gestation is referred to a tertiary care center after her obstetrician detected a significant abnormality on a routine fetal ultrasound. The ultrasound reveals a severe developmental defect involving the fetal head. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Anencephaly


The ultrasound findings are consistent with anencephaly, an open neural tube defect caused by the incomplete closure of the neural tube. This condition results in the absence of the cranial calvaria, exposing the brain tissue. Key ultrasound signs include the "frog eye sign," characterized by prominent orbits due to missing cranial bones, and the "shower cap sign," where the disorganized brain tissue protrudes outward. Anencephaly can be detected on ultrasound as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.

 

Prevention includes pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation (5 mg daily for at least three months before conception), which significantly reduces the risk of such neural tube defects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Craniosynostosis: Premature fusion of cranial sutures leading to abnormal skull shape but does not involve the absence of cranial bones or exposed brain tissue.

 

Option C. Encephalocele: Characterized by herniation of brain tissue through a skull defect, usually covered by a sac, unlike the complete absence of cranial structures seen in anencephaly.

 

Option D. Holoprosencephaly: A failure of the brain to divide into two hemispheres, often associated with midline facial defects, but does not involve the absence of the cranial bones as seen in anencephaly.

 

Educational Objective:


Anencephaly is an open neural tube defect characterized by the absence of the cranial calvaria and disorganized brain tissue. Early prenatal ultrasound detection and pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation are key to reducing the risk of this severe congenital anomaly

questions.text: A young girl has been experiencing repeated instances of yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was only 3 months old. Given her immune system's condition, which of the listed vaccines should not be administered to her? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Measles/MMR

 

Based on the information provided, the girl child has a history of recurrent yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was 3 months old. This suggests that she may have an underlying immunodeficiency.

 

In this scenario, the measles/MMR vaccine would be contraindicated due to the risk of causing a severe infection in an immunocompromised individual.

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS OF LIVE VACCINES –

 

  • Immunodeficient individuals (Symptomatic HIV infection) except BCG vaccine
  • Immunosuppressed individuals (patient with leukemia or patients on antimetabolites, steroids or radiation)
  • Pregnancy (except Yellow fever)

 

Additional Information

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killed IPV (Inactivated Polio Vaccine): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it does not contain live virus.

 

Option C. DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Option D. TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus and Diphtheria): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live vaccines like Measles/MMR should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals due to the risk of severe infection. Instead, inactivated or subunit vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens, should be used.

questions.text: Fibers from the structure marked in blue, terminate at which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Red nucleus

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle is the peduncle that is highlighted in the picture. Deep cerebellar nuclei that extend to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus are connected by fibres to the superior cerebellar peduncle. The fibres of the ventral spinocerebellar tract are also present.

 

 

 

All of the efferent fibres from the dentate, emboliform, and globose nuclei Majority of efferents from the fastigial nucleus pass via inferior cerebellar peduncle though few may pass via superior peduncle. The caudal mesencephalon is where its fibres decussate, and they are intended to synapse in the thalamus and opposite red nucleus. Only afferent fibres from the contralateral pontine nuclei are present in the middle cerebellar peduncle. Afferent and efferent fibres that travel to the vestibular nuclei are both present in the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

The image below summarizes the various tracts in the cerebellar unit.

 

 

  • It has two surfaces - superior and inferior separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles
    • Superior cerebellar peduncle -connecting to the midbrain
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the pons
    • Inferior cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the medulla oblongata

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle, also known as the brachium conjunctivum, is a major white matter tract connecting the cerebellum to the midbrain. Its fibers originate in the cerebellum, ascend, and decussate (cross over) at the level of the midbrain to end primarily in the contralateral red nucleus and the thalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fastigial nucleus: The fastigial nucleus is one of the four deep cerebellar nuclei (others being the globose, emboliform, and dentate nuclei). While the fastigial nucleus does send fibers out of the cerebellum, it primarily connects through the inferior cerebellar peduncle to the vestibular nuclei and the reticular formation, not the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option B. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is involved in motor learning and coordination. It primarily sends fibers to the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle, and it receives cerebellar feedback, but not directly from the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option D. Subthalamus: The subthalamus is part of the diencephalon and is closely related to the basal ganglia circuitry, particularly in the indirect pathway. While the subthalamus does receive some cerebellar input, the primary connection from the superior cerebellar peduncle is to the red nucleus and not directly to the subthalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The red nucleus is located in the midbrain and plays a role in motor coordination. Fibers from the cerebellum via the superior cerebellar peduncle decussate and terminate primarily in the contralateral red nucleus. From the red nucleus, some of these fibers continue on to the thalamus. Thus, the red nucleus is a major target of the superior cerebellar peduncle fibers.

questions.text: Anti-D vaccine is not given in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks

 

The Anti-D vaccine (anti-D immunoglobulin) is typically administered to prevent Rh sensitization in Rh-negative women who might be exposed to Rh-positive fetal blood. It is given to protect against the formation of anti-Rh antibodies that could affect future pregnancies. The vaccine is not given after an intrauterine transfusion because this procedure is performed to treat severe fetal anemia in cases where the mother is Rh-positive or the indirect Coombs test (ICT) is positive, indicating that the mother has already been sensitized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis at 16 weeks: Anti-D vaccine is given after amniocentesis to prevent Rh sensitization, as the procedure can cause fetal blood to mix with maternal blood.

 

Option B. Manual removal of placenta: Anti-D vaccine is administered after manual removal of the placenta to prevent sensitization, as this procedure can result in significant feto-maternal hemorrhage.

 

Option D. MTP at 63 days: Anti-D vaccine is given after medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) to prevent Rh sensitization if the mother is Rh-negative and the fetus is Rh-positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-D vaccine is not given after intrauterine transfusion, as this procedure is used to treat severe fetal anemia and does not require further prophylaxis against Rh sensitization.

 

Ref: Page no 919, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the finding marked by the arrow in the below image: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vossius ring

 

  • The image shows a Vossius ring, which is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity seen on the anterior surface of the lens.
  • It is caused by brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens and is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.
  • The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, producing an impression of the iris on the lens.
  • The ring usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil.
  • The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weiss ring: Is a floater which may be seen by the patient as a circle or other large solitary lesion. It is the detached former attachment to the margin of the optic disc. It is seen in posterior vitreous detachment and is not confirmatory. It is seen in the image below.

 

 

Option C. A Fleischer's ring: Is usually observed in keratoconus, representing epithelial iron deposits. It is seen best with a cobalt blue filter.

 

 

Option D. Kayser-Fleischer ring: Is observed in Wilson's disease, due to intraocular deposition of copper. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also knowns as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vossius ring is an important clinical marker of previous blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by pigment imprint from the iris on the lens surface, mirroring the size of the contracted pupil at the time of impact.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child is found to have a unilateral undescended testis on the right side during a routine physical exam. A diagnostic laparoscopy is performed, which reveals blind-ending testicular vessels and vas deferens on the right side. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nothing to be done

 

Blind-ending vas deferens and testicular vessels imply anorchism or testicular agenesis. In such cases, no further exploration is required.

 

When diagnostic laparoscopy reveals blind-ending testicular vessels, it indicates the absence or nonviable nature of the testis. In such cases, there is no surgical intervention required because there is no viable testis to locate or bring down. The appropriate management approach is to monitor the patient and provide counseling regarding the absence of the testis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inguinal exploration: Inguinal exploration involves surgical exploration of the inguinal canal to locate and bring down an undescended testis. However, in this case, the diagnostic laparoscopy has already revealed blind-ending testicular vessels on the right side. This finding indicates that the testis is absent or nonviable, and no further surgical exploration is needed.

 

Option B. Abdominal exploration: Abdominal exploration is typically performed when an undescended testis is suspected to be located within the abdominal cavity. However, in this case, the laparoscopy has confirmed the absence of a viable testis on the right side.

 

Option C. Scrotal exploration: Scrotal exploration involves surgical exploration of the scrotum to locate and bring down an undescended testis. However, in this case, the laparoscopy findings have already established the absence of a viable testis on the right side, making scrotal exploration unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A unilateral undescended testis refers to a condition in which only one of the testes has not descended into the scrotum, while the other testis has descended normally. This condition is relatively common in male infants and can occur on either the right or left side.

 

Here are some key points about unilateral undescended testis:

 

  1. Incidence: It is one of the most common congenital anomalies in male infants, with the majority of cases involving the left testis.
  2. Diagnosis: Unilateral undescended testis is typically diagnosed during a physical examination, such as a routine well-baby check or pediatric evaluation.
  3. Management: The management of unilateral undescended testis may vary based on the age of the child and the specific circumstances. In many cases, the testis will descend into the scrotum on its own within the first few months of life. If the testis has not descended by the age of 6 months, treatment options may include hormone therapy to stimulate descent or surgical intervention (orchidopexy) to bring the testis down into the scrotum.
  4. Importance of Treatment: The goal of treatment is to ensure that the undescended testis is properly positioned in the scrotum. This is important for several reasons, including the potential impact on fertility and the increased risk of testicular cancer in undescended testes if left untreated.

questions.text: The following sets of X-rays are suggestive of:(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness for few hours that improves with activity.
