    • Question mark (?) posture due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Hip and shoulder joint arthritis may occur.
    • Peripheral joints may also be involved in some.
    • Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation.
       
  • Spine radiograph:
    • Loss of lumbar lordosis (Straightening).
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.
    • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
    • Calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacrotuberous ligaments.
    • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons & ligaments.
    • Trolley/Tram-track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
    • Erosions of anterior corners of vertebral body causing squaring of vertebral body.
    • Bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) with vertical orientation bridging vertebral bodies are seen. Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

 

A. Trolley/Tram track sign; B. Bamboo Spine

 

 

Dagger Sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. It is the osteoclast that appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity. Long bone X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen. Skull X-ray reveal “cotton wool” or osteoporosis circumscripta, thickening of diploic area. Vertebral cortical thickening at superior and inferior end plates creates a picture frame vertebrae and diffuse sclerosis causing ivory vertebrae. Pelvic radiograph shows sclerotic iliopectineal line (Brim sign), fusion or disruption of sacroiliac joints, etc.

 

 

Blade of grass appearance

 

 

 

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis. In rheumatoid arthritis, upper cervical spine & hip joint are less commonly involved. There is atlantoaxial joint subluxation when cervical spine is involved. Lumbar spine is usually spared. The chronic inflammatory synovitis in the cervical spine results in severity that progresses to bone erosion and ligamentous laxity, leading to late spinal instability. The most common radiological presentations of spinal involvement in RA are: atlantoaxial subluxation, cranial settling (also known as basilar impression, atlantoaxial impaction or superior migration of the odontoid, the most severe form of spinal instability in RA), subaxial subluxation or a combination of them.

 

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism. Hyperparathyroidism maybe primary (due to adenoma or hyperplasia), secondary (due to persistent hypocalcemia) or tertiary (when secondary hyperplasia leads to autonomous overactivity). Parathyroid adenoma is most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. It presents with subperiosteal resorption, and replacement of endosteal cavitation marrow by vascular granulation and fibrous tissue (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Classical and pathognomic feature of hyperparathyroidism is subperiosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges on radial aspect. Clinical features are Abdominal groans (dyspepsia), psychic moans, renal stones and weak bones (Groans, moans, stones and Bones). Hyperparathyroidism causes diffuse rarefaction of bone (osteopenia) and osteitis fibrosa cystica. Radiological Features includes subperiosteal resorption of terminal tufts of phalanges, lateral end of clavicle and symphysis pubis, loss of lamina dura (i.e. thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth is seen as thin white line, is resorbed), irregular, diffuse rarefaction of bones, i.e. generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae, brown tumor, salt pepper appearance of skull.

 

 

 

Resorption of lamina dura

 

 

Salt-pepper skull

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The radiographic images given the question shows:

 

A. Bamboo spine

 

B. Sacroiliitis

 

C. Loss of lumbar lordosis

 

D. Dagger’s sign

 

These features are characteristic of Ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluent aphasia

 

The posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus is where Wernicke's area is located, which is crucial for language comprehension. Lesions in this area lead to Wernicke's aphasia, which is a type of fluent aphasia. Patients with this type of aphasia exhibit fluent but often meaningless speech and have significant difficulties in understanding spoken language. Their speech is typically characterized by normal flow and articulation but includes nonsensical phrases and incorrect word substitutions (neologisms).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-fluent aphasia: This type of aphasia, typically associated with damage to Broca’s area in the frontal lobe, results in slow, labored speech and struggle in forming words, though comprehension often remains intact.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: In anomic aphasia, the person can speak fluently and understand speech but has difficulty naming objects and words, typically not linked to damage in the superior temporal gyrus.

 

Option D. Conduction aphasia: This arises from damage to the arcuate fasciculus, the brain structure that connects Wernicke's area to Broca’s area. It is characterized by fluent speech with frequent errors, good comprehension, but poor repetition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regions anterior to the central sulcus are motor areas and posterior are sensory areas. Hence temporal gyrus involvement causes a fluent aphasia.

 

 

Reference - KV Krishna Das textbook of Medicine 5th edition

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Years lost due to premature death

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL)

 

Definition: YPLL is based on Years of life lost through premature death

 

Importance:

 

  • YPLL occurs before the age to which a dying person could have expected to survive
  • YPLL is a type of mortality indicator

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Years lost to morbidity refers to the time spent living with a disease or disability, which is not directly related to the concept of years of potential life lost.

 

Option C. Years lost to disability is a component of disability-adjusted life years (DALY). DALY Is BEST measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

 

DALY = YLL (Years of lost life) + YLD (Years lost to disability)

 

Option D. life would account into QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years)

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a measure that quantifies the impact of premature death on a population by calculating the number of years not lived by individuals who die before reaching a specified age. It highlights the significance of early mortality and its impact on society.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and anxiety presents to his primary care physician with a persistent dry cough that has not responded to his usual inhaler treatments. He describes the cough as particularly bothersome at night, affecting his sleep and daily functioning. Over-the-counter cough suppressants have provided little relief, and he expresses concern about his inability to control the cough. The physician considers prescribing a medication known for its ability to suppress the cough reflex centrally without the significant analgesic effects seen in other medications of its class. Which of the following medications is specifically recognized for its centrally acting antitussive properties?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Levopropoxyphene


Levopropoxyphene is a centrally acting opioid antitussive that works by acting as a strong and partial µ receptor agonist, reducing the cough reflex. It is specifically used for its antitussive properties and is distinct from other opioids as it does not provide significant analgesic effects, making it particularly suitable for patients needing cough suppression without the risk of pain management side effects. Levopropoxyphene is the preferred choice when the goal is targeted cough suppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tramadol: Tramadol is primarily used for pain relief and has some activity on µ-opioid receptors. While it can provide some cough suppression, it is not specifically used as an antitussive and carries a risk of sedation and other opioid-related side effects.

 

Option B. Codeine: Codeine is an opioid that has both antitussive and analgesic effects, making it less specific for cough suppression. Its dual role limits its use specifically as an antitussive, and it carries additional risks such as sedation and dependence.

 

Option D. Butorphanol: Butorphanol is an opioid agonist-antagonist primarily used for pain relief, especially in migraine or perioperative settings. It is not typically used as an antitussive due to its primary analgesic indications.

 

Educational Objective:


Levopropoxyphene is a centrally acting opioid specifically used as an antitussive, reducing the cough reflex without significant analgesic effects. It is distinct from other opioids which are primarily used for pain relief but may incidentally suppress cough.

questions.text: WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is related to: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Therapeutic abortion

 

The World Medical Association's (WMA) Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical considerations surrounding therapeutic abortion. This declaration emphasizes that medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) should be conducted under specific conditions to ensure it is ethical and safe.

 

The key focus areas of the Oslo Declaration include:

 

MTP must be done only due to:

 

  1. Health Reasons: Therapeutic abortion should only be performed when it is medically necessary for the health of the patient. This may include physical, mental, or social reasons that could adversely affect the well-being of the patient.
  2. Informed Consent: Both the patient and the healthcare provider must fully understand and agree to the procedure. It is essential that both parties are convinced of the necessity and appropriateness of the abortion.
  3. Legal Compliance: The procedure must comply with the local laws governing abortion in the specific region, territory, or country. Legal regulations vary, and it is crucial to adhere to them.
  4. Competent Personnel: The procedure should be carried out by competent surgeons. If the situation allows, trained professional health workers who are competent and authorized by law can also perform the procedure.

 

These principles ensure that therapeutic abortions are conducted in a manner that prioritizes the safety, rights, and well-being of the patient while adhering to ethical and legal standards.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hunger: The Declaration of Oslo is not related to hunger. Hunger and food security issues are addressed by different international organizations and declarations, but not by this specific WMA declaration.

 

Option B. State of prisoners: The Oslo Declaration does not deal with the treatment or state of prisoners. Other international conventions, like the Geneva Conventions, cover the rights and treatment of prisoners.

 

Option C. Ethics in Medical Research: Although the WMA has issued other declarations related to ethics in medical research, such as the Declaration of Helsinki, Nuremberg code and Belmont report.

 

Additional Information

 

Declaration of Geneva: related to the physician's dedication to humanitarian goals of medicine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical guidelines surrounding therapeutic abortion, emphasizing health reasons, informed consent, legal compliance, and the requirement for competent medical personnel.

questions.text: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for her myopia. She is now complaining of headaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on her: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tonometry

 

  • The image depicts the use of an Applanation tonometry. It is based on the applanation principle described by Imbert and Fick. With regards to applanation tonometry, the law states that pressure (P) can be approximated by the force (F) necessary to flatten the cornea in a fixed area, divided by the surface (S) of the flattened area. The Imbert-Fick law is defined as P=F/S.
  • The dynamic contour tonometer (Pascal) for tonometry looks as

 

 

  • Intraocular pressure (IOP) readings obtained with this tonometer are not influenced by central corneal thickness.
  • The Pascal tonometer is the preferred tonometer for measuring IOP in post-LASIK corneas.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pachymetry: This test measures the thickness of the cornea. It is important for assessing the cornea pre-LASIK but is not depicted in the image nor directly associated with measuring IOP.

 

 

Option C. Autorefractometry: This procedure determines the refractive error and prescription for glasses or contact lenses. It does not involve contact with the eye as depicted and is unrelated to IOP measurement.

 

 

Option D. A scan: This ultrasound test measures the length of the eye and is primarily used in cataract surgery planning. It does not involve the measurement of IOP.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tonometry, especially applanation tonometry, is crucial for monitoring intraocular pressure post-LASIK surgery to ensure no adverse effects on eye pressure, which could lead to symptoms like headaches and eye pain as described. This test is essential for the ongoing evaluation of patients' eye health following refractive surgery.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and periorbital puffiness following chemotherapy. Investigations reveal hyperuricemia and hyperkalemia. What is the next best step in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydration

 

The clinical scenario and the laboratory investigations are suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. Aggressive hydration is the next best step in the management of this condition.

 

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) can occur after chemotherapy due to release of intracellular components.
  • Increased uric acid levels cause hyperuricemia, while release of potassium and phosphate leads to hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Hyperphosphatemia leads to reciprocal depression of serum calcium causing hypocalcemia.
  • TLS can result in renal failure due to deposition of uric acid crystals, calcium phosphate, and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Signs and symptoms of TLS include abdominal pain, dysuria, oliguria, flank pain, anorexia, vomiting, cramps, seizures, altered mental status, tetany, weakness, and paralysis.
  • The Cairo-Bishop criteria are used to assess the severity of TLS.
  • Management of TLS includes measuring electrolytes and aggressive hydration before starting therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Probenecid: Probenecid inhibits the organic anion transporter in the nephron, thereby inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid. However, it is contraindicated in TLS as it increases the risk of uric acid stones due to increased uric acid levels.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Allopurinol and febuxostat are xanthine oxidase inhibitors that decrease uric acid synthesis and treat hyperuricemia. While they are useful in managing hyperuricemia, aggressive hydration is the first-line treatment in TLS to prevent renal failure.

 

Option D. Rasburicase: Rasburicase is an enzyme that degrades uric acid and is preferred in TLS over allopurinol for rapidly reducing uric acid levels. However, initial aggressive hydration is crucial before administering rasburicase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aggressive hydration is the first-line management for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) to prevent renal failure and facilitate the excretion of released intracellular components.

questions.text: In the case of an elderly male presenting with meningitis, a gram stain of the CSF sample shows the presence of gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following statements accurately pertains to the motility of the responsible microorganism? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Motile at 25° C, non-motile at 37°C

 

  • The provided case involves an elderly man with meningitis, and the smear analysis indicates the presence of a gram-positive bacillus, strongly indicative of a Listeria infection. Listeria exhibits motility at 25°C but loses its ability to move at 37°C.

 

LAB DIAGNOSIS OF LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES

 

  • Motility: shows differential motility, which is due to temperature dependent flagella expression) 
    • Tumbling type of motility at 25°C
    • Non-Motile at 37°C
  • Culture → Blood agar, Chocolate agar
  • Selective media → PALCAM agar

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Meningitis → DOC → Ampicillin in combination with gentamicin for synergistic effect
  • Penicillin allergy → Cotrimoxazole
  • In febrile gastroenteritis → Amoxicillin

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes exhibits motility at 25°C but is non-motile at 37°C.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the point from A to C in the given flowchart depicting the natural history of a disease? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lead time

 

Lead time is defined as the interval between the point a condition is detected through screening and the Time it would normally have been detected due to appearance and reporting of signs and symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening time:  This term refers to the period during which screening tests are conducted to detect disease in asymptomatic individuals.

 

Option C. Lag time:  This term is generally used to describe a delay between the onset of an event and its detection or measurement. In the context of disease, lag time could refer to the delay between symptom onset and diagnosis.

 

Option D. Generation time:  This term is typically used in epidemiology to describe the time interval between the infection of a host and the subsequent transmission of the disease to another host. It does not relate to the timeline of diagnosis within an individual patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead time is the interval between the detection of a disease through screening and its usual time of diagnosis due to symptom presentation.

 

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening (leading the time of diagnosis)

 

Early detection of disease due to screening (B rather than C) will ensure earlier institution of treatment, thus better prognosis.

questions.text:
Which diagnostic investigation is utilized to identify the condition characterized by a 40-year-old man displaying abrupt erythematous painful lesions on the trunk and face, joint pain, and glove and stock anesthesia? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Nerve examination
  2. Skin biopsy
  3. Slit skin smear
  4. Mantoux test
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

The clinical scenario points to a case of leprosy. The diagnosis of this condition requires nerve examination, skin biopsy, and a slit skin smear (option B - 1, 2, 3).

 

The clinical presentation described suggests a condition called leprosy or Hansen's disease, which can cause skin lesions, nerve damage resulting in anaesthesia, and joint pain.

 

1. Nerve examination: An essential part of the diagnosis of leprosy involves the examination of nerves for enlargement and tenderness, which can indicate nerve damage due to the disease.

 

2. Skin biopsy: A biopsy of the affected skin can be taken and histologically examined for the presence of Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium that causes leprosy.

 

3. Slit skin smear:  This test involves taking a sample from the skin (usually from the earlobes or from lesions) and staining it for acid-fast bacilli, which is a characteristic of Mycobacterium leprae.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Mantoux test:

 

  • The Mantoux test is used to diagnose tuberculosis, not leprosy.
  • It involves the tuberculin skin test (TST) to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium leprae are both acid-fast bacilli.
  • The Mantoux test is specific for TB and does not directly aid in the diagnosis of leprosy

 

Characteristic clinical features of Hansen’s disease / Leprosy

 

  • Mycobacterium leprae is the cause of the chronic granulomatous disease known as leprosy.
  • The typical incubation period for leprosy is 2 to 12 years.
  • It frequently manifests as a visible skin lesion, such as a hypopigmented or erythematous macule, or as a numb spot on the skin.
  • The face, buttocks, trunk, and extensor aspects of the limbs are frequently affected by lesions.
  • Skin, cutaneous, and peripheral nerves, as well as mucous membranes, are all impacted.
  • The posterior tibial nerve, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves, are the peripheral nerves that are most frequently affected.
  • The facial nerve is the cranial nerve that is involved most frequently.
  • Both nerve function and hair growth are compromised by the lesions.
  • Burns or ulcers on the amputation limb may also be present in the patients.

 

Additional Information

 

Classification systems of leprosy:

 

Ridley-Jopling classification

 

  • Tuberculoid (TT)
  • Borderline tubercular (BT)
  • Borderline (BB)
  • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
  • Lepromatous (LL)

 

WHO classification:

 

  • Paucibacillary
  • Multibacillary

 

Cardinal signs for the diagnosis of leprosy:

 

 

  • The presence of two of the three signs can establish the diagnosis of leprosy. Other tests done for diagnosis of leprosy include nerve biopsy in pure neural leprosy and PGL-1 antibody in cases with low bacterial load.
  • Mantoux test is not useful in diagnosis of leprosy. This is the test which helps to explain the prognosis of leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate diagnostic investigations for a suspected case of leprosy include nerve examination, skin biopsy, and slit skin smear to detect the presence of Mycobacterium leprae and to assess the extent of nerve damage.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 28 page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition 1385, 1386, 1388

questions.text: A 45-year-old male farmer is brought to the emergency department with severe muscle stiffness, painful spasms, and difficulty breathing. He mentions that the symptoms began shortly after accidentally consuming some seeds from a plant while working on his farm. On examination, he has continuous muscle contractions and appears anxious. His vital signs are stable, and there is no significant medical history or signs of substance abuse. Which of the following plant toxins is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans: C) Strychnine


Strychnine, the primary toxin found in Strychnos nux-vomica, is a potent neurotoxin that acts by blocking glycine receptors in the spinal cord, leading to an overactive neuronal state characterized by severe muscle rigidity, painful convulsions, and potentially life-threatening respiratory failure. This clinical presentation aligns closely with strychnine poisoning, where excessive stimulation of motor neurons results in continuous muscle spasms.

 

Strychnos nux-vomica seeds

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coniine: Found in Conium maculatum (Hemlock), coniine causes neuromuscular blockade leading to flaccid paralysis rather than convulsions, making it an unlikely cause in this case.

 

Option B. Ricin: Ricin, a toxin from Ricinus communis (Castor bean), inhibits protein synthesis and leads to severe systemic toxicity, including gastrointestinal distress, organ failure, and shock, but does not present with muscle rigidity and convulsions.

 

Option D. Digoxin: A cardiac glycoside from Digitalis purpurea (Foxglove), digoxin toxicity typically involves cardiac arrhythmias, nausea, and visual disturbances, rather than the severe muscle spasms and convulsions seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:


Strychnine poisoning should be suspected in patients presenting with severe muscle stiffness and convulsions after ingesting plant material, as it blocks inhibitory neurotransmission in the spinal cord, leading to continuous muscle excitation and respiratory distress. Immediate recognition and supportive care are crucial.

questions.text: Based on the image, a 60-year-old male patient with diabetes presents with progressive skin lesions. What could be the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

The image above displays a central rodent ulcer, which indicates basal cell carcinoma. This malignant tumor exhibits characteristics of slow local invasion and mainly affects the pilosebaceous skin.

 

Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC):

 

  • The most significant predisposing factor for basal cell carcinoma is exposure to ultraviolet radiation. Other risk factors include ionizing radiation, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and arsenic exposure.
  • Basal cell carcinoma predominantly affects middle-aged or elderly men with a history of excessive sun exposure, often among individuals with white skin, aged between 40 to 80 years.

 

Morphologically, basal cell carcinoma can be of 2 types:

 

1. Localized types: These are more common and include:

 

  • Nodular and nodulocystic BCC: Representing the majority of cases, these appear as pearly, waxy nodules with rolled borders and sometimes central ulceration or depression, known as umbilication.

 

 

  • Pigmented BCC: These are similar to nodular BCC but contain melanin, giving them a darker appearance.
  • Nevoid BCC: This type is rarer and can resemble benign moles.

 

2. Generalized types: These are less common and can be more challenging to treat due to their growth patterns:

 

  • Superficial multifocal and spreading BCC: Often appearing as scaly, erythematous patches that can be mistaken for eczema or psoriasis.
  • Infiltrative BCC: These grow more aggressively and can invade deeper tissues.
  • Cicatrizing (or sclerosing) BCC: This type can cause scarring as it grows.

 

While nodular BCC is the most common form, it is important for medical practitioners to recognize the less common types due to their growth patterns and potential for tissue destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

 

  • It typically presents as a firm, red nodule or a flat sore with a scaly crust as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • While it's possible for diabetic patients to develop SCC, the description provided fits BCC more closely.

 

Option C. Melasma

 

  • It is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is usually seen on the face.
  • It is more common in women, especially during pregnancy, and is not typically associated with progressive lesions.

 

Option D. Discoid lupus erythematosus

 

  • It often presents as a chronic rash with red, inflamed, and scaly patches that can cause scarring, usually on the face, ears, and scalp, as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is an autoimmune condition and not directly linked to diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly patient, progressive pearly or waxy skin lesions, especially if located on sun-exposed areas, are likely indicative of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 4.15, 51.3, 88.10-12, 141.1-16

Robbins basic pathology 10th edition page no 1148

Bailey & Loves short practice of surgery 27th edition Page no 599, 604-6011

questions.text: In an isolated mitochondria, in a medium containing Succinate, Fumarate, ADP and Pi, ATPs were produced. Later a compound was added, and oxidative phosphorylation was decreased. What’s that compound? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oligomycin

 

  • Oligomycin is an antibiotic that inhibits ATP synthase, a key enzyme complex in oxidative phosphorylation. It blocks the flow of protons (H+) through ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis. As a result, adding oligomycin would indeed decrease oxidative phosphorylation, leading to a reduction in ATP production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP): 2,4-dinitrophenol is a chemical uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation. It disrupts the proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane, making it leaky to protons. This uncoupling reduces the efficiency of ATP production but doesn't directly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option C. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It blocks the transfer of electrons from ubiquinone to cytochrome c, disrupting the electron flow in the chain.

 

Option D. Rotenone: Rotenone is an inhibitor of complex I in the electron transport chain. It prevents the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone, disrupting electron flow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligomycin specifically targets ATP synthase and inhibits ATP synthesis in oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, the compound that was added to the isolated mitochondria, leading to a decrease in oxidative phosphorylation

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 123

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to your clinic for her postpartum checkup. She mentions that she has been exclusively breastfeeding her newborn and is concerned about meeting her own nutritional needs in order to ensure the best for her baby. She asks you about specific nutrient supplementation she might need during this period of lactation. Compared to her pregnancy, which nutrient would you recommend she should pay particular attention to increasing? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Vitamin A

 

  • The requirement for Vitamin A increases during lactation more than during pregnancy.
  • Vitamin A is essential for ensuring the quality of breast milk, which is the sole source of nutrition for a newborn.
  • It plays a critical role in the development of the baby’s immune system and visual function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to the latest Nutritional Guidelines,

 

  • Requirement in Pregnancy > Lactation → Proteins; Zinc; Folic Acid; Iron
  • Requirement in Lactation > Pregnancy → Vitamin A; Iodine; Vitamin C; Carbohydrates, Calcium
  • Requirement in Pregnancy = Lactation → Vitamin D; Calcium

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis for a young male presenting with Leucotrichia and lesions as depicted in the image is? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental vitiligo

 

Localized, unilateral depigmented macules can be seen in the image. This characteristic and a history of leukotrichia point to the diagnosis of segmental vitiligo in the patient.

 

Vitiligo happens because the basal layer lacks melanocytes due to autoimmune destruction by auto antibodies.

 

The gradual loss of melanocytes causes a localized depigmentation to take place.

 

It is categorized as:

 

  1. Segmental vitiligo: This form of vitiligo is characterized by unilateral depigmented macules in a dermatomal or segmental pattern. The presence of Leucotrichia (white or colorless hair) within the lesion is a strong clinical indicator of segmental vitiligo. The image shows a pattern consistent with segmental vitiligo.
  2. Non-segmental vitiligo: which appears as bilateral macules distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal vitiligo: This is characterized by one or more macules or patches in one area without any recognizable pattern as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C. Piebaldism: It is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that is present at birth. The hallmark of piebaldism is a white forelock as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The distribution of lesions is usually symmetrical and remains stable throughout life, which differs from the presentation in the image.

 

Option D. Nevus depigmentosus: This is a congenital, stable hypopigmented patch that does not progress or change with time. Unlike vitiligo, it does not show Leucotrichia, and the lesion does not spread.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segmental vitiligo presents with one or more macules in a dermatomal or segmental pattern, often accompanied by Leucotrichia.

 

Ref - Rooks Textbook of dermatology 9th Edition page no 88.34

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post-menopausal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a mass with feeding vessel as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrial polyp

 

  • The image is an ultrasound image of the uterus with a thickened endometrium.
  • The presence of a feeding vessel is very suggestive of an endometrial polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibroid uterus: Fibroid uterus would generally show a different pattern on ultrasound and is characterized by increased vascularity, but it wouldn't typically present with a single feeding vessel like an endometrial polyp.

 

Option C. Endometrial carcinoma: In endometrial carcinoma, the endometrium would be irregularly thickened with loss of endo-myometrial junction and cystic spaces with increased vascularity throughout.

 

Option D. Leiomyosarcoma: Leiomyosarcoma, similar to fibroids, would show increased vascularity but with more aggressive features and not a solitary feeding vessel as seen in polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a single feeding vessel in a mass seen on ultrasonography is highly suggestive of an endometrial polyp.

 

Ref: Page no 460, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As a part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was done. What is the principle of this test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibodies

 

The principle of the Paul-Bunnell test is based on heterophile antibodies.

 

Heterophile antibodies agglutinate shared antigens.

 

Paul-Bunnell test is used diagnosing for infectious mononucleosis, wherein heterophile antibodies agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

 

The Weil-Felix reaction is another example heterophile agglutination test. Here the common antigen is shared between typhus rickettsia and some strains of proteus bacilli. It is helpful in the serodiagnosis of typhus fevers.

 

Streptococcus MG agglutination test for primary atypical pneumonia and the cold agglutination test for mycoplasma (primary atypical) pneumonia are also based on heterophile antibody.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complement fixation: Incorrect: The complement fixation test is based on the ability of antigen-antibody complexes to fix complement. This is a different mechanism from the heterophile antibody agglutination used in the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option B. Super-antigens: Incorrect: Superantigens are a class of antigens that cause excessive activation of the immune system by non-specific activation of T-cells, leading to massive cytokine release. This is not related to the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option D. Haptens: Incorrect: Haptens are small molecules that elicit an immune response only when attached to a large carrier such as a protein. The Paul-Bunnell test does not involve haptens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Paul-Bunnell test is based on the detection of heterophile antibodies, which agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, and is used in the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis.

choices.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.text: Which nerve innervates the muscle marked in the given image? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dorsal scapular nerve

 

The above image shows the levator scapulae muscle, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve.

 

Dorsal scapular nerve arises from the brachial plexus, usually from the cervical nerve root C5. Muscles Supplied are Rhomboid major, Rhomboid minor and Levator scapulae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suprascapular nerve: It is derived from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, which is formed by the union of the C5 and C6 nerve roots. Muscles Supplied are Supraspinatus and Infraspinatus.

 

Option C. From the dorsal rami of C1: It is a spinal nerve root. Muscles Supplied are Suboccipital muscles (rectus capitis posterior major, rectus capitis posterior minor, obliquus capitis superior, and obliquus capitis inferior).

 

Option D. Subscapular nerve: It Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and contains fibers from C5 and C6. Muscles Supplied are Subscapularis and teres major muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appendicular group of back muscles and their innervations include: Superficial (appendicular) group of back muscles
